repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Social Sector
            Technical Assistance Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Sector Technical Assistance
            Credit for Bosnia and Herzegovina had the following ratings:
            the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was
            likely, the institutional development impact was modest, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            The lessons learned indicate that the pairing of a TA
            operation with an adjustment lending is an excellent
            combination and can lead to the successful implementation of
            difficult reform program. If technical assistance projects
            like Social Sector Technical Assistance Credit (SOTAC) are
            being designed as a companion project to a structural
            adjustment operation it is important to ensure that the
            teams working on both operations are almost identical or, at
            least, are led by the same task team leader. In low-capacity
            environments focusing Technical Assistance on direct
            capacity building may produce more sustainable impact.
            Limited procurement options might result in non-delivery of
            planned technical assistance assignments that are important
            for the country's development agenda. A capacity
            building component for implementation should be built into
            the project, in those cases when there is not enough time to
            do so in the preparation phase of the project. NGOs can be a
            driving force in the development of innovative projects and
            deliver significant results for relatively small amounts of
            funding, when those NGOs are guided by capable and
            open-minded Centers of Social Work management.

5084967.trustfund:
TF029816-BOSNIA & HERZEGOVINA SOCIAL
            SECTOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CREDIT

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia-Herzegovina - Social Sector
            Technical Assistance Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Sector Technical Assistance
            Credit Project (SOTAC) aims at providing a sustainable
            system of social protection that targets spending more
            effectively on the poorest and is based on reliable social
            statistics, and creating an improved labor relations
            framework in order to stimulate employment growth. This
            project will be a companion credit to a proposed Social
            Sector Adjustment Credit (SOSAC). The project has three
            components. 1) Social Protection Policy will include
            technical assistance, training, workshops and study tours in
            different aspects of social protection policy. Specifically,
            the technical assistance will be provided for: i) social
            assistance; ii) special reviews of employment institutes;
            iii) disability programs; iv) labor legislation and labor
            market; v) social protection expenditure strategy; and vi)
            social statistics. 2) Social Protection Institutional
            Strengthening and Public Information will support a number
            of areas: a) functional review of social protection in both
            entities; b) pubic information campaigns on objectives and
            nature of labor market and social protection reforms; c)
            other training; d) client registries for centers for social
            work; and e) non-government organization/Centers for Social
            Work innovation consultancies. 3) Project Implementation
            will support costs of project management, procurement, and
            financial management.
